Indeed, if it isn't distinctive, then it isn't a style. A creative person is someone who imagines what other people cannot. Their value to us lies in expanding our own possibilities. Walls fall. We break out. Art releases what was lost. Jeanette Winterson          Sometimes it seems that our lives have been watered down. That somehow we have been cheated of the true meaning of what is before us. Especially here in America, millions of people live comfortable lifestyles: they have money, they have place, they have success. But still many of us are bored and unhappy. We wake up every morning, go to work, go to school, and come home without feeling a thing. We are de facto disenchanted and nobody really knows why. Our imagination dies long before our bodies die.          Jeanette Winterson is a writer whose work seems to be aimed at changing this for herself and, if we will listen to her, perhaps for us as well. Winterson reveals both the beauty and the horror with which we are confronted on a daily basis. She shows us new universes within our own, and parallel universes outside our own. Her writing teaches us to read between the lines of our everyday lives. Even when this is not an obvious message delivered through the content of her stories, we find it within her language. Her words reveal and unfold layers of unrealized meaning on every page, until the reader is gently lowered back into his or her own world with a new fascination and awe for what already existed.          Winterson's writing rejects our conventional perception of life. She reveals the shallow fulfillment inherent in traditional values, expands our notion of time and reality, and gives us new insight on our existing realities. This is not only apparent through the content of Winterson's stories but also through her use of unusual and varied narrative structures. Winterson's work is deeply creative; she is constantly moving between territories which seem to be uncharted and new, and she never seems to write the same way twice. Thus her characters' refusal to accept the conventional means of living are paralleled by her own refusal to abide by the conventional means of storytelling. Winterson wants us to read and live beyond convention, as she writes and her characters live.          On a literal level, nearly all of Jeanette Winterson's writing contains some sort of rejection of traditional values or societal norms. The story "Newton," from The World and Other Places portrays a distorted world in which traditional ideas and values are exaggerated to the point of domination. These ideas are rejected by Winterson through the character Tom, who is "the stranger" in his world (163). Much like Camus' character in L'Etranger, to whom Winterson alludes, Tom is an unconventional character who is not a typical member of his society. Tom escapes from his hometown, Newton, which represents an exaggerated societal ideal, and in the end he says that unlike the other inhabitants, his "hills are ripe, and the water leaps at [his] throat . . ." (175). With this one sentence , Winterson cleverly reveals the reward of enchantment found by Tom through his rejection of convention. This is mirrored in numerous other characters throughout The World And Other Places. In "The Green Square," a character does not physically leave the society with which she grapples, but instead discovers that it is essential to her life that she "find, everyday, a green square to walk in"(203). The "green square" represent the character's realization of the beauty in the mundane aspects of her life. Although the stories present seemingly different realities, one might view them as a portrayal of the same character from two different perspectives. "Newton" possesses a fairy tale-like quality, beginning with the familiarly simple line "This is the story of Tom," (163) while "The Green Square" is not far out of the conventional contemporary idiom, but both stories portray traditional values as boundaries standing between a character and his or her undiscovered love for everyday life. Another story, which possesses a mythic and allegorical quality, "The Three Friends" uses the metaphor of a floorless house to represent traditional values. The three characters who set out in search of "that which cannot be found," first reach a "house that celebrated ceilings and denied floors" which offers them gold (49). The house represents the backwards and contradictory values of our society: value of material goods over more necessary things, and the placement of boundaries where no floor exists, so to speak. Throughout the story, the friends amass many material goods and conventional successes, but none of these end their search. The pursuit of material goods ultimately becomes the pursuit of "that which cannot be found." Thus Winterson portrays the material values of society as unattainable goals without real fulfillment, whilst suggesting a "green square to walk in" as a true necessity-the foundation necessary for real life. Winterson wants us to keep our imaginations alive.          Beyond a rejection of our traditional values, Winterson seems to urge a general abandonment of the way we are inclined to view life. Her stories often discard the linearity of basic conventional laws of time and space, embracing instead works of extended reality, or as Michiko Kakutani called them, " worlds in which the usual laws of plausibility are suspended." Winterson builds realities out of her metaphors, as opposed to using them as tools to describe the literal. Her stories become both allegorical and literal, and seem to uniquely bridge the territory which lies between the two. In "Disappearance I" and "Disappearance II" rooms literally disappear from houses. In "Disappearance I," Winterson depicts a futuristic situation, similar to George Orwell's 1984 in its relation to present time. Sleep has been nearly outlawed, and the main character is obsessed with sleeping. Eventually, her bedroom, along with her lover, is stolen and destroyed. Thus Winterson builds a reality that is literally based on the perpetual hustle and bustle of our society, and her character's beautiful rejection of this reality reveals the horror inherent in certain aspects of our own. As in the case with Orwell's great novel 1984 , "Disappearance I" can actually be read as a distorted perception of today's world in which time, sleep, and dreams are taken for granted. The story functions on both literal and allegorical levels, and we are unsure at times which way to approach it. This ambiguity causes us to examine our present reality in a broader sense. In another story, "The World and Other Places," the main character literally flies in an airplane onto her parents' lawn to visit them. The character is one who has abandoned her life on the earth's surface in order to "do what [she] needs to do, which is to look for [her]self"(98). Thus Winterson transforms the concept of philosophical inquiry into the literal lifestyle of a carefree pilot who travels the world at will, revealing the place in which the literal and the allegorical are one and the same. Both stories connect imaginary and real worlds and abandon conventional laws in order to reveal true meaning in ordinary life. "Sleep now and hope to dream," Winterson's character from "Disappearance I" tells us (116). Winterson wants us to keep our dreams alive. She reminds us that we are in too much of a hurry to enjoy life or to think about it enough. She wants us to slow down and take care of ourselves. She wants us to fly the airplanes in our heads, and to love the importance of sleep and dreams, even if these things are in opposition to societal expectations.          Winterson not only writes between the lines of our lives, she writes between the lines of our foundational texts. She makes constant reference to the Bible, and to Greek mythology, reinventing and reinterpreting them to mean new things. The story of Orion and Artemis, or Diana, becomes a tale of rape and revenge, where in its conventional sense it could be regarded as an example of the misogynistic folklore which pervades our society's broad literary canon. In "The Poetics of Sex," Winterson's character ironically calls her female lover "my New Testament" (42), and continually uses references from the New Testament to develop her ideas. This is ironic because most traditional interpretations of the New Testament have proclaimed it to be anti-homosexual. Winterson rejects this traditional interpretation and adopts her own, which is rich with unmined beauty and is non-discriminatory. Such a reinvention or reinterpretation of texts which are foundational to our society is an example of Winterson's encouraging us to read between the lines, and to notice beyond the obvious detail.          The character named Picasso appears frequently both in Winterson's stories and novels. The World and Other Places is littered with allusions to the painter. Picasso is the name of the narrator's lover in "The Poetics of Sex," and of a protagonist in one of Winterson's novels Art and Lies . A reference to Picasso is, throughout Winterson's writing, applied to a character like Tom in "Newton," who sees the world with a view different from those who surround him. The character Picasso in "The Poetics of Sex" tells us that most people "don't know how to look at pictures" (39); he embraces instead a view of the world unbounded by time and space. Winterson often associates such a perception with Picasso himself.          Ultimately, we are led not only to see Picasso in Winterson's characters, but also in herself as well. As the artist Picasso pioneered the cubist style of painting, in which an object is painted from various perspectives of time and space, Winterson seems to have in many ways, adopted this approach to writing. Her rejection of traditional values in her stories is paralleled by her rejection of the traditional narrative structure. Her stories often unfold without the conventional organization associated with plot and setting. She employs a variety of particularly unusual narrative structures to tell her stories, and she seems to be intentionally stylistically inconsistent in her choice of them. Winterson employs the style of the contemporary short story for some of her stories, like "24-Hour Dog" and "Atlantic Crossing." Other stories, like "The Three Friends" or "Orion" seem to be either a modern version, or parody of mythic-type narratives. By juxtaposing such opposite styles, Winterson creates her own specific style. "A Green Square" is a perfectly realistic story, whereas " O'Brien's First Christmas" is clearly a fairy-tale both in its familiar plot structure, and in it's use of a fairy to enact magical events. Her structure seem to be toying with our fundamental perceptions of time and space. "Disappearance I," "Newton," and "Turn of the World" all depict alternate realities, sometimes displaced by time, and others outside the physical realm. Many stories, including "The Poetics of Sex" and "The Lives of Saints" reject linear plot, and lead us in full circle instead.          Despite their contrasting qualities, most of these widely varying structures used by Winterson seem to embody common, or closely similar thematic content. Like Picasso's cubist work, The World and Other Places seems to paint the same subject from various perspectives of time and space. In many of the stories in World, a character is left by a lover, close friend, or, as is the case in "Disappearance I," even a room. This disappearance is often coupled with a sort of rejection of linear time, creating a sense of continuity for all things. In "24-Hour Dog," the expression of this continuity is decisive: "He found me out I knew he would. The strange thing is that although I have given him away, I can't lose him, and he can't die. There he is. Forever, part of the pattern, the dance, and running beside me, joyful" (16). In other stories, such as "The Poetics of Sex," a disappeared character is reintroduced into the narrative without explanation, as if he or she had never left. But most telling of all, and central to Written on the Body, The Passion, "Lives of Saints, " "Disappearance I," and so many other pieces, are the situations in which a character seems to fall even more feverishly in love with someone or something that they have already physically lost. A character's love poems for the lost are often rich with catharsis. Winterson consoles the reader, who has undoubtedly left or been left before, as we all have, with this concept of continuity. In the opening line of Written on the Body , we are asked "Why is the measure of love loss?" And Winterson goes on to try and change how we measure love. She shows us the undeniable and ever-present beauty of being left and of leaving, provoking us to transcend the conventional perceptions of loss and its means of existence, time.          Not only does Jeanette Winterson reveal beauty through her thematic material, but she also invariably finds an incredible and delicate universe within mundane aspects of daily life to revel in and celebrate. The puppy is "a universe of play," (5) the grass sings to us (166), and houses can fly (119). Reality is more than it seems to be. However, Winterson's extended reality is closely grounded in our own. She wants us to couple our own reality with the enchantment that is so pervasive and abundant in her stories. She offers us her gift of extra-sensory perception in a book with a beating heart.          But as revealed by her own statement that "art releases what was lost," Winterson's repetitive thematic content and concern with the art of perception are both merely part of a much bigger scheme. As a writer, she is concerned with returning the lost meaning into our lives. Her ever-present yet disappearing characters could be regarded as personifications, or concrete realizations of this lost meaning. With this in mind, thematic material that at fist seems self concerned and petty takes on a world of implication. Winterson's lost lovers are there even though they seem to be gone. The beauty inherent in everyday life is there, wherever and whenever it seems to have been lost.          Jeanette Winterson is tricky with her sickness. She is sick of our houses with ceilings and no floors and wants us to build houses instead with floors and no ceilings, houses that deny limits and embrace sheltered truths that help us deny the limits. She sees the power and beauty in both imagination and reality, and she finds no need to distinguish between the two, as both exist co-dependently, like structural elements of a house with no ceiling. In short, Jeanette Winterson wants to release, through her own art, the love for life that has been lost. She writes for our very lives and hers.          Works Cited          Kakutani, Michiko. Offered every semester. 4 points.      The course is designed for students who can understand and speak conversational Chinese related to daily-life situations, but have not learned to read/write Chinese characters. This includes students who were raised in a non-Chinese speaking country but in a home where Mandarin Chinese dialect was spoken, and/or students who have acquired a certain level of Mandarin Chinese language proficiency (primarily speaking and listening) by living or working in a Chinese speaking country/region for an extended time. Students who understand or speak a Chinese dialect other than Mandarin should consult the Chinese language faculty about whether this is the appropriate course for them. This course aims to develop students’ correct pronunciation, grammatical accuracy and overall competence in reading and writing.      Intermediate Chinese for Advanced Beginners   EAST-UA 232 Prerequisite: EAST-UA 231 or the equivalent. For students with background in Chinese (see course description above). Offered every semester. 4 points.   Continuation of Elementary Chinese for Advanced Beginners.      Elementary Chinese I EAST-UA 201 Prerequisite: none. Offered every semester. 4 points. Open to students with no or little training in Chinese. Designed to develop and reinforce language skills in listening, speaking, reading, and writing as it relates to everyday life situations. The objectives are: to master the Chinese phonetic system (pinyin and tones) with satisfactory pronunciation; to understand the construction of commonly used Chinese Characters (both simplified and traditional) and learn to write them correctly; to understand and use correctly basic Chinese grammar and sentence structures; to build up essential vocabulary; to read and write level appropriate passages; to become acquainted with aspects of Chinese culture and society related to the course materials. Elementary Chinese II EAST-UA 202 Prerequisite: EAST-UA 201 or the   equivalent. Offered every semester. 4 points.   Continuation of Elementary Chinese I. Designed to reinforce and further develop language skills in listening, speaking, reading and writing as it  relates to everyday life situations.      Intermediate Chinese I  EAST-UA 203 Prerequisite: EAST-UA 202 or the equivalent. Offered every semester. 4 points per term. Designed to consolidate the student's overall aural-oral proficiency. Focuses gradually on the written aspect of Chinese. The objectives are: to be able to obtain information from extended conversation; to both express and expound on, in relative length, feelings and opinions on common topics; to expand vocabulary and learn to decipher meaning of compound words; to develop reading comprehension of extended narrative, expository and simple argumentative passages; to solve non-complex textual problems with the aid of dictionaries; to write in relative length personal narratives, informational narratives, comparison and discussion of viewpoints with level appropriate vocabulary and grammatical accuracy, as well as basic syntactical cohesion; to continue being acquainted with aspects of Chinese culture and society related to the course materials.      Intermediate Chinese II  EAST-UA 204 Prerequisite: EAST-UA 203 or the equivalent. Offered every semester. 4   points per term.     Continuation of Intermediate Chinese I, focusing semi-formal usage of  Chinese language when discussing more academic-flavored cultural or social  topics .       Advanced Chinese I EAST-UA 205 Prerequisite: EAST-UA 204 or the equivalent. Offered every semester. 4 points per term. Designed to further develop proficiency in speaking and writing through readings on and discussions of socio-cultural topics relevant to today's China. Focuses on improving reading comprehension and writing skills. The objectives are: to further improve oral communicative competence by incorporating semi-formal or formal usages; to acquire vocabulary and patterns necessary for conducting semi-formal or formal discussions of socio-cultural topics; to increase reading speed of texts with more advanced syntax; to learn to make context-based guess about the meaning of a new word, conduct sentence analysis and solve textual problems with the aid of dictionaries; to write and present more fully developed narratives or reasoned and structured arguments in length; to learn to employ basic rhetoric methods; to learn to appreciate stylistic usage of Chinese language. Indeed, if it isn't distinctive, then it isn't a style. A creative person is someone who imagines what other people cannot. Their value to us lies in expanding our own possibilities. Walls fall. We break out. Art releases what was lost. Jeanette Winterson          Sometimes it seems that our lives have been watered down. That somehow we have been cheated of the true meaning of what is before us. Especially here in America, millions of people live comfortable lifestyles: they have money, they have place, they have success. But still many of us are bored and unhappy. We wake up every morning, go to work, go to school, and come home without feeling a thing. We are de facto disenchanted and nobody really knows why. Our imagination dies long before our bodies die.          Jeanette Winterson is a writer whose work seems to be aimed at changing this for herself and, if we will listen to her, perhaps for us as well. Winterson reveals both the beauty and the horror with which we are confronted on a daily basis. She shows us new universes within our own, and parallel universes outside our own. Her writing teaches us to read between the lines of our everyday lives. Even when this is not an obvious message delivered through the content of her stories, we find it within her language. Her words reveal and unfold layers of unrealized meaning on every page, until the reader is gently lowered back into his or her own world with a new fascination and awe for what already existed.          Winterson's writing rejects our conventional perception of life. She reveals the shallow fulfillment inherent in traditional values, expands our notion of time and reality, and gives us new insight on our existing realities. This is not only apparent through the content of Winterson's stories but also through her use of unusual and varied narrative structures. Winterson's work is deeply creative; she is constantly moving between territories which seem to be uncharted and new, and she never seems to write the same way twice. Thus her characters' refusal to accept the conventional means of living are paralleled by her own refusal to abide by the conventional means of storytelling. Winterson wants us to read and live beyond convention, as she writes and her characters live.          On a literal level, nearly all of Jeanette Winterson's writing contains some sort of rejection of traditional values or societal norms. The story "Newton," from The World and Other Places portrays a distorted world in which traditional ideas and values are exaggerated to the point of domination. These ideas are rejected by Winterson through the character Tom, who is "the stranger" in his world (163). Much like Camus' character in L'Etranger, to whom Winterson alludes, Tom is an unconventional character who is not a typical member of his society. Tom escapes from his hometown, Newton, which represents an exaggerated societal ideal, and in the end he says that unlike the other inhabitants, his "hills are ripe, and the water leaps at [his] throat . . ." (175). With this one sentence , Winterson cleverly reveals the reward of enchantment found by Tom through his rejection of convention. This is mirrored in numerous other characters throughout The World And Other Places. In "The Green Square," a character does not physically leave the society with which she grapples, but instead discovers that it is essential to her life that she "find, everyday, a green square to walk in"(203). The "green square" represent the character's realization of the beauty in the mundane aspects of her life. Although the stories present seemingly different realities, one might view them as a portrayal of the same character from two different perspectives. "Newton" possesses a fairy tale-like quality, beginning with the familiarly simple line "This is the story of Tom," (163) while "The Green Square" is not far out of the conventional contemporary idiom, but both stories portray traditional values as boundaries standing between a character and his or her undiscovered love for everyday life. Another story, which possesses a mythic and allegorical quality, "The Three Friends" uses the metaphor of a floorless house to represent traditional values. The three characters who set out in search of "that which cannot be found," first reach a "house that celebrated ceilings and denied floors" which offers them gold (49). The house represents the backwards and contradictory values of our society: value of material goods over more necessary things, and the placement of boundaries where no floor exists, so to speak. Throughout the story, the friends amass many material goods and conventional successes, but none of these end their search. The pursuit of material goods ultimately becomes the pursuit of "that which cannot be found." Thus Winterson portrays the material values of society as unattainable goals without real fulfillment, whilst suggesting a "green square to walk in" as a true necessity-the foundation necessary for real life. Winterson wants us to keep our imaginations alive.          Beyond a rejection of our traditional values, Winterson seems to urge a general abandonment of the way we are inclined to view life. Her stories often discard the linearity of basic conventional laws of time and space, embracing instead works of extended reality, or as Michiko Kakutani called them, " worlds in which the usual laws of plausibility are suspended." Winterson builds realities out of her metaphors, as opposed to using them as tools to describe the literal. Her stories become both allegorical and literal, and seem to uniquely bridge the territory which lies between the two. In "Disappearance I" and "Disappearance II" rooms literally disappear from houses. In "Disappearance I," Winterson depicts a futuristic situation, similar to George Orwell's 1984 in its relation to present time. Sleep has been nearly outlawed, and the main character is obsessed with sleeping. Eventually, her bedroom, along with her lover, is stolen and destroyed. Thus Winterson builds a reality that is literally based on the perpetual hustle and bustle of our society, and her character's beautiful rejection of this reality reveals the horror inherent in certain aspects of our own. As in the case with Orwell's great novel 1984 , "Disappearance I" can actually be read as a distorted perception of today's world in which time, sleep, and dreams are taken for granted. The story functions on both literal and allegorical levels, and we are unsure at times which way to approach it. This ambiguity causes us to examine our present reality in a broader sense. In another story, "The World and Other Places," the main character literally flies in an airplane onto her parents' lawn to visit them. The character is one who has abandoned her life on the earth's surface in order to "do what [she] needs to do, which is to look for [her]self"(98). Thus Winterson transforms the concept of philosophical inquiry into the literal lifestyle of a carefree pilot who travels the world at will, revealing the place in which the literal and the allegorical are one and the same. Both stories connect imaginary and real worlds and abandon conventional laws in order to reveal true meaning in ordinary life. "Sleep now and hope to dream," Winterson's character from "Disappearance I" tells us (116). Winterson wants us to keep our dreams alive. She reminds us that we are in too much of a hurry to enjoy life or to think about it enough. She wants us to slow down and take care of ourselves. She wants us to fly the airplanes in our heads, and to love the importance of sleep and dreams, even if these things are in opposition to societal expectations.          Winterson not only writes between the lines of our lives, she writes between the lines of our foundational texts. She makes constant reference to the Bible, and to Greek mythology, reinventing and reinterpreting them to mean new things. The story of Orion and Artemis, or Diana, becomes a tale of rape and revenge, where in its conventional sense it could be regarded as an example of the misogynistic folklore which pervades our society's broad literary canon. In "The Poetics of Sex," Winterson's character ironically calls her female lover "my New Testament" (42), and continually uses references from the New Testament to develop her ideas. This is ironic because most traditional interpretations of the New Testament have proclaimed it to be anti-homosexual. Winterson rejects this traditional interpretation and adopts her own, which is rich with unmined beauty and is non-discriminatory. Such a reinvention or reinterpretation of texts which are foundational to our society is an example of Winterson's encouraging us to read between the lines, and to notice beyond the obvious detail.          The character named Picasso appears frequently both in Winterson's stories and novels. The World and Other Places is littered with allusions to the painter. Picasso is the name of the narrator's lover in "The Poetics of Sex," and of a protagonist in one of Winterson's novels Art and Lies . A reference to Picasso is, throughout Winterson's writing, applied to a character like Tom in "Newton," who sees the world with a view different from those who surround him. The character Picasso in "The Poetics of Sex" tells us that most people "don't know how to look at pictures" (39); he embraces instead a view of the world unbounded by time and space. Winterson often associates such a perception with Picasso himself.          Ultimately, we are led not only to see Picasso in Winterson's characters, but also in herself as well. As the artist Picasso pioneered the cubist style of painting, in which an object is painted from various perspectives of time and space, Winterson seems to have in many ways, adopted this approach to writing. Her rejection of traditional values in her stories is paralleled by her rejection of the traditional narrative structure. Her stories often unfold without the conventional organization associated with plot and setting. She employs a variety of particularly unusual narrative structures to tell her stories, and she seems to be intentionally stylistically inconsistent in her choice of them. Winterson employs the style of the contemporary short story for some of her stories, like "24-Hour Dog" and "Atlantic Crossing." Other stories, like "The Three Friends" or "Orion" seem to be either a modern version, or parody of mythic-type narratives. By juxtaposing such opposite styles, Winterson creates her own specific style. "A Green Square" is a perfectly realistic story, whereas " O'Brien's First Christmas" is clearly a fairy-tale both in its familiar plot structure, and in it's use of a fairy to enact magical events. Her structure seem to be toying with our fundamental perceptions of time and space. "Disappearance I," "Newton," and "Turn of the World" all depict alternate realities, sometimes displaced by time, and others outside the physical realm. Many stories, including "The Poetics of Sex" and "The Lives of Saints" reject linear plot, and lead us in full circle instead.          Despite their contrasting qualities, most of these widely varying structures used by Winterson seem to embody common, or closely similar thematic content. Like Picasso's cubist work, The World and Other Places seems to paint the same subject from various perspectives of time and space. In many of the stories in World, a character is left by a lover, close friend, or, as is the case in "Disappearance I," even a room. This disappearance is often coupled with a sort of rejection of linear time, creating a sense of continuity for all things. In "24-Hour Dog," the expression of this continuity is decisive: "He found me out I knew he would. The strange thing is that although I have given him away, I can't lose him, and he can't die. There he is. Forever, part of the pattern, the dance, and running beside me, joyful" (16). In other stories, such as "The Poetics of Sex," a disappeared character is reintroduced into the narrative without explanation, as if he or she had never left. But most telling of all, and central to Written on the Body, The Passion, "Lives of Saints, " "Disappearance I," and so many other pieces, are the situations in which a character seems to fall even more feverishly in love with someone or something that they have already physically lost. A character's love poems for the lost are often rich with catharsis. Winterson consoles the reader, who has undoubtedly left or been left before, as we all have, with this concept of continuity. In the opening line of Written on the Body , we are asked "Why is the measure of love loss?" And Winterson goes on to try and change how we measure love. She shows us the undeniable and ever-present beauty of being left and of leaving, provoking us to transcend the conventional perceptions of loss and its means of existence, time.          Not only does Jeanette Winterson reveal beauty through her thematic material, but she also invariably finds an incredible and delicate universe within mundane aspects of daily life to revel in and celebrate. The puppy is "a universe of play," (5) the grass sings to us (166), and houses can fly (119). Reality is more than it seems to be. However, Winterson's extended reality is closely grounded in our own. She wants us to couple our own reality with the enchantment that is so pervasive and abundant in her stories. She offers us her gift of extra-sensory perception in a book with a beating heart.          But as revealed by her own statement that "art releases what was lost," Winterson's repetitive thematic content and concern with the art of perception are both merely part of a much bigger scheme. As a writer, she is concerned with returning the lost meaning into our lives. Her ever-present yet disappearing characters could be regarded as personifications, or concrete realizations of this lost meaning. With this in mind, thematic material that at fist seems self concerned and petty takes on a world of implication. Winterson's lost lovers are there even though they seem to be gone. The beauty inherent in everyday life is there, wherever and whenever it seems to have been lost.          Jeanette Winterson is tricky with her sickness. She is sick of our houses with ceilings and no floors and wants us to build houses instead with floors and no ceilings, houses that deny limits and embrace sheltered truths that help us deny the limits. She sees the power and beauty in both imagination and reality, and she finds no need to distinguish between the two, as both exist co-dependently, like structural elements of a house with no ceiling. In short, Jeanette Winterson wants to release, through her own art, the love for life that has been lost. She writes for our very lives and hers.          Works Cited          Kakutani, Michiko.
